data.value: Member initializer values should not be redundant

data.name: S3610_Description
data.value: Calling GetType() on a nullable object returns the underlying value type. Thus, comparing the returned Type object to typeof(Nullable<SomeType>) doesn't make sense. The comparison either throws an exception or the result can be known at compile time.

data.name: S3610_Title
data.value: Nullable type comparison should not be redundant

data.name: S3626_Description
data.value: Jump statements, such as return, yield break, goto, and continue let you change the default flow of program execution, but jump statements that direct the control flow to the original direction are just a waste of keystrokes.

data.name: S3626_Title
data.value: Jump statements should not be redundant

data.name: S3649_Description
data.value: Applications that execute SQL commands should neutralize any externally-provided values used in those commands. Failure to do so could allow an attacker to include input that changes the query so that unintended commands are executed, or sensitive data is exposed.

data.name: S3649_Title
data.value: User-provided values should be sanitized before use in SQL statements

data.name: S3655_Description
data.value: Nullable value types can hold either a value or null. The value held in the nullable type can be accessed with the Value property, but .Value throws an InvalidOperationException when the value is null. To avoid the exception, a nullable type should always be tested before .Value is accessed.

data.name: S3655_Title
data.value: Empty nullable value should not be accessed

data.name: S3693_Description
data.value: It may be a good idea to raise an exception in a constructor if you're unable to fully flesh the object in question, but not in an exception constructor. If you do, you'll interfere with the exception that was originally being thrown. Further, it is highly unlikely that an exception raised in the creation of an exception will be properly handled in the calling code, and the unexpected, unhandled exception will lead to program termination.

data.name: S3693_Title
data.value: Exception constructors should not throw exceptions

data.name: S3717_Description
data.value: NotImplementedException is often used to mark methods which must be implemented for the overall functionality to be complete, but which the developer wants to implement later. That's as opposed to the NotSupportedException which is thrown by methods which are required by base classes or interfaces, but which are not appropriate to the current class.

data.name: S3776_Description
data.value: Cognitive Complexity is a measure of how hard the control flow of a method is to understand. Methods with high Cognitive Complexity will be difficult to maintain.

data.name: S3776_Title
data.value: Cognitive Complexity of methods should not be too high

data.name: S3869_Description
data.value: Not surprisingly, the SafeHandle.DangerousGetHandle method is dangerous. That's because it may not return a valid handle. Using it can lead to leaks and vulnerabilities. While it is possible to use the method successfully, it's extremely difficult to do correctly, so the method should simply be avoided altogether.

data.name: S3871_Description
data.value: The point of having custom exception types is to convey more information than is available in standard types. But custom exception types must be public for that to work.

data.name: S3872_Description
data.value: The name of a method should communicate what it does, and the names of its parameters should indicate how they're used. If a method and its parameter have the same name it is an indication that one of these rules of thumb has been broken, if not both. Even if by some trick of language that's not the case, it is still likely to confuse callers and maintainers.

data.name: S3872_Title
data.value: Parameter names should not duplicate the names of their methods

data.name: S3874_Description
data.value: Passing a parameter by reference, which is what happens when you use the out or ref parameter modifiers, means that the method will receive a pointer to the argument, rather than the argument itself. If the argument was a value type, the method will be able to change the argument's values. If it was a reference type, then the method receives a pointer to a pointer, which is usually not what was intended. Even when it is what was intended, this is the sort of thing that's difficult to get right, and should be used with caution.

data.name: S3874_Title
data.value: "out" and "ref" parameters should not be used

data.name: S3875_Description
data.value: The use of == to compare to objects is expected to do a reference comparison. That is, it is expected to return true if and only if they are the same object instance. Overloading the operator to do anything else will inevitably lead to the introduction of bugs by callers. On the other hand, overloading it to do exactly that is pointless; that's what == does by default.

data.name: S3875_Title
data.value: "operator==" should not be overloaded on reference types

data.name: S3876_Description
data.value: Strings and integral types are typically used as indexers. When some other type is required, it typically indicates design problems, and potentially a situation where a method should be used instead.

data.name: S3876_Title
data.value: Strings or integral types should be used for indexers

data.name: S3877_Description
data.value: It is expected that some methods should be called with caution, but others, such as ToString, are expected to "just work". Throwing an exception from such a method is likely to break callers' code unexpectedly.

data.name: S3877_Title
data.value: Exceptions should not be thrown from unexpected methods

data.name: S3880_Description
data.value: Finalizers come with a performance cost due to the overhead of tracking the life cycle of objects. An empty one is consequently costly with no benefit or justification.

data.name: S3881_Description
data.value: The IDisposable interface is a mechanism to release unmanaged resources, if not implemented correctly this could result in resource leaks or more severe bugs.

data.name: S3884_Description
data.value: CoSetProxyBlanket and CoInitializeSecurity both work to set the permissions context in which the process invoked immediately after is executed. Calling them from within that process is useless because it's to late at that point; the permissions context has already been set.

data.name: S3885_Description
data.value: The parameter to Assembly.Load includes the full specification of the dll to be loaded. Use another method, and you might end up with a dll other than the one you expected.

data.name: S3887_Description
data.value: Using the readonly keyword on a field means that it can't be changed after initialization. However, when applied to collections or arrays, that's only partly true. readonly enforces that another instance can't be assigned to the field, but it cannot keep the contents from being updated. That means that in practice, the field value really can be changed, and the use of readonly on such a field is misleading, and you're likely to not be getting the behavior you expect.

data.name: S3887_Title
data.value: Mutable, non-private fields should not be "readonly"

data.name: S3889_Description
data.value: Thread.Suspend and Thread.Resume can give unpredictable results, and both methods have been deprecated. Indeed, if Thread.Suspend is not used very carefully, a thread can be suspended while holding a lock, thus leading to a deadlock. Other safer synchronization mechanisms should be used, such as Monitor, Mutex, and Semaphore.

data.name: S3897_Description
data.value: The IEquatable<T> interface has only one method in it: Equals(<T>). If you've already written Equals(T), there's no reason not to explicitly implement IEquatable<T>. Doing so expands the utility of your class by allowing it to be used where an IEquatable is called for.

data.name: S3898_Description
data.value: If you're using a struct, it is likely because you're interested in performance. But by failing to implement IEquatable<T> you're loosing performance when comparisons are made because without IEquatable<T>, boxing and reflection are used to make comparisons.

data.name: S3900_Description
data.value: A public method can be called from anywhere, which means you should validate parameters to be within the expected constraints. In general, checking against null is recommended defensive programming.

data.name: S3900_Title
data.value: Arguments of public methods should be validated against null

data.name: S3902_Description
data.value: Using Type.Assembly to get the current assembly is nearly free in terms of performance; it's a simple property access. On the other hand, Assembly.GetExecutingAssembly() can take up to 30 times as long because it walks up the call stack to find the assembly.

data.name: S3903_Description
data.value: Types are declared in namespaces in order to prevent name collisions and as a way to organize them into the object hierarchy. Types that are defined outside any named namespace are in a global namespace that cannot be referenced in code.

data.name: S3903_Title
data.value: Types should be defined in named namespaces

data.name: S3904_Description
data.value: If no AssemblyVersionAttribute is provided, the same default version will be used for every build. Since the version number is used by The .NET Framework to uniquely identify an assembly this can lead to broken dependencies.

data.name: S3906_Description
data.value: Delegate event handlers (i.e. delegates used as type of an event) should have a very specific signature:

data.name: S3906_Title
data.value: Event Handlers should have the correct signature

data.name: S3908_Description
data.value: Since .Net Framework version 2.0 it is not necessary to declare a delegate that specifies a class derived from System.EventArgs. The System.EventHandler<TEventArgs> delegate mechanism should be used instead as it allows any class derived from EventArgs to be used with that handler.

data.name: S3908_Title
data.value: Generic event handlers should be used

data.name: S3909_Description
data.value: The NET Framework 2.0 introduced the generic interface System.Collections.Generic.IEnumerable<T> and it should be preferred over the older, non generic, interfaces.

data.name: S3909_Title
data.value: Collections should implement the generic interface

data.name: S3925_Description
data.value: The ISerializable interface is the mechanism to control the type serialization process. If not implemented correctly this could result in an invalid serialization and hard to detect bugs.

data.name: S3926_Description
data.value: Fields marked with System.Runtime.Serialization.OptionalFieldAttribute are serialized just like any other field. But such fields are ignored on deserialization, and retain the default values associated with their types. Therefore, deserialization event handlers should be declared to set such fields during the deserialization process.

data.name: S3926_Title
data.value: Deserialization methods should be provided for "OptionalField" members

data.name: S3927_Description
data.value: Serialization event handlers that don't have the correct signature will simply not be called, thus bypassing any attempts to augment the automated de/serialization.

data.name: S3927_Title
data.value: Serialization event handlers should be implemented correctly

data.name: S3928_Description
data.value: Some constructors of the ArgumentException, ArgumentNullException, ArgumentOutOfRangeException and DuplicateWaitObjectException classes must be fed with a valid parameter name. This rule raises an issue in two cases:

data.name: S3928_Title
data.value: Parameter names used into ArgumentException constructors should match an existing one

data.name: S3956_Description
data.value: System.Collections.Generic.List<T> is a generic collection that is designed for performance and not inheritance. For example, it does not contain virtual members that make it easier to change the behavior of an inherited class. That means that future attempts to expand the behavior will be spoiled because the extension points simply aren't there. Instead, one of the following generic collections should be used:

data.name: S3956_Title
data.value: "Generic.List" instances should not be part of public APIs

data.name: S3962_Description
data.value: The value of a static readonly field is computed at runtime while the value of a const field is calculated at compile time, which improves performance.

data.name: S3963_Description
data.value: When a static constructor serves no other purpose that initializing static fields, it comes with an unnecessary performance cost because the compiler generates a check before each static method or instance constructor invocation.

data.name: S3966_Description
data.value: A proper implementation of IDisposable.Dispose should allow for it to be called multiple times on the same object, however this is not guaranteed and could result in an exception being thrown.

data.name: S3966_Title
data.value: Objects should not be disposed more than once

data.name: S3967_Description
data.value: A jagged array is an array whose elements are arrays. It is recommended over a multidimensional array because the arrays that make up the elements can be of different sizes, which avoids wasting memory space.

data.name: S3967_Title
data.value: Multidimensional arrays should not be used

data.name: S3971_Description
data.value: GC.SuppressFinalize requests that the system not call the finalizer for the specified object. This should only be done when implementing Dispose as part of the Dispose Pattern.

data.name: S3972_Description
data.value: Code is clearest when each statement has its own line. Nonetheless, it is a common pattern to combine on the same line an if and its resulting then statement. However, when an if is placed on the same line as the closing } from a preceding else or else if, it is either an error - else is missing - or the invitation to a future error as maintainers fail to understand that the two statements are unconnected.

data.name: S3972_Title
data.value: Conditionals should start on new lines

data.name: S3981_Description
data.value: The size of a collection and the length of an array are always greater than or equal to zero. So testing that a size or length is greater than or equal to zero doesn't make sense, since the result is always true. Similarly testing that it is less than zero will always return false. Perhaps the intent was to check the non-emptiness of the collection or array instead.

data.name: S3981_Title
data.value: Collection sizes and array length comparisons should make sense

data.name: S3984_Description
data.value: Creating a new Exception without actually throwing it is useless and is probably due to a mistake.

data.name: S3984_Title
data.value: Exception should not be created without being thrown

data.name: S3990_Description
data.value: Assemblies should conform with the Common Language Specification (CLS) in order to be usable across programming languages. To be compliant an assembly has to indicate it with System.CLSCompliantAttribute.

data.name: S3990_Title
data.value: Assemblies should be marked as CLS compliant

data.name: S3992_Description
data.value: Assemblies should explicitly indicate whether they are meant to be COM visible or not. If the ComVisibleAttribute is not present, the default is to make the content of the assembly visible to COM clients.

data.name: S3992_Title
data.value: Assemblies should explicitly specify COM visibility

data.name: S3993_Description
data.value: When defining custom attributes, System.AttributeUsageAttribute must be used to indicate where the attribute can be applied. This will determine its valid locations in the code.

data.name: S3993_Title
data.value: Custom attributes should be marked with "System.AttributeUsageAttribute"

data.name: S3994_Description
data.value: String representations of URIs or URLs are prone to parsing and encoding errors which can lead to vulnerabilities. The System.Uri class is a safe alternative and should be preferred. At minimum, an overload of the method taking a System.Uri as a parameter should be provided in each class that contains a method with an apparent Uri passed as a string.

data.name: S3994_Title
data.value: URI Parameters should not be strings

data.name: S3995_Description
data.value: String representations of URIs or URLs are prone to parsing and encoding errors which can lead to vulnerabilities. The System.Uri class is a safe alternative and should be preferred.

data.name: S3995_Title
data.value: URI return values should not be strings

data.name: S3996_Description
data.value: String representations of URIs or URLs are prone to parsing and encoding errors which can lead to vulnerabilities. The System.Uri class is a safe alternative and should be preferred.

data.name: S3996_Title
data.value: URI properties should not be strings

data.name: S3997_Description
data.value: String representations of URIs or URLs are prone to parsing and encoding errors which can lead to vulnerabilities. The System.Uri class is a safe alternative and should be preferred.

data.name: S3997_Title
data.value: String URI overloads should call "System.Uri" overloads

data.name: S3998_Description
data.value: A thread acquiring a lock on an object that can be accessed across application domain boundaries runs the risk of being blocked by another thread in a different application domain. Objects that can be accessed across application domain boundaries are said to have weak identity. Types with weak identity are:

data.name: S3998_Title
data.value: Threads should not lock on objects with weak identity

data.name: S4000_Description
data.value: The IntPtr and UIntPtr types are used to access unmanaged memory, usually in order to use C or C++ libraries. If such a pointer is not secured by making it private, internal or readonly, it can lead to a vulnerability allowing access to arbitrary locations.

data.name: S4000_Title
data.value: Pointers to unmanaged memory should not be visible

data.name: S4002_Description
data.value: This rule raises an issue when a disposable type contains fields of the following types and does not implement a finalizer:

data.name: S4004_Description
data.value: A writable collection property can be replaced by a completely different collection. Making it readonly prevents that while still allowing individual members to be set. If you want to allow the replacement of the whole collection the recommended pattern is to implement a method to remove all the elements (e.g. System.Collections.List<T>.Clear) and a method to populate the collection (e.g. System.Collections.List<T>.AddRange).

data.name: S4005_Description
data.value: String representations of URIs or URLs are prone to parsing and encoding errors which can lead to vulnerabilities. The System.Uri class is a safe alternative and should be preferred.

data.name: S4005_Title
data.value: "System.Uri" arguments should be used instead of strings

data.name: S4015_Description
data.value: Changing an inherited member to private will not prevent access to the base class implementation.

data.name: S4015_Title
data.value: Inherited member visibility should not be decreased

data.name: S4016_Description
data.value: If an enum member's name contains the word "reserved" it implies it is not currently used and will be change in the future. However changing an enum member is a breaking change and can create significant problems. There is no need to reserve an enum member since a new member can be added in the future, and such an addition will usually not be a breaking change.

data.name: S4016_Title
data.value: Enumeration members should not be named "Reserved"

data.name: S4017_Description
data.value: A nested type is a type argument that is also a generic type. Calling a method with such a nested type argument requires complicated and confusing code. It should be avoided as much as possible.

data.name: S4017_Title
data.value: Method signatures should not contain nested generic types

data.name: S4018_Description
data.value: The best way to determine the type of a generic method is by inference based on the type of argument that is passed to the method. This is not possible when a parameter type is missing from the argument list.

data.name: S4018_Title
data.value: Generic methods should provide type parameters

data.name: S4019_Description
data.value: When a method in a derived class has the same name as a method in the base class but with a signature that only differs by types that are weakly derived (e.g. object vs string), the result is that the base method becomes hidden.

data.name: S4019_Title
data.value: Base class methods should not be hidden

data.name: S4022_Description
data.value: By default the storage type of an enum is Int32. In most cases it is not necessary to change this. In particular you will not achieve any performance gain by using a smaller data type (e.g. Byte) and may limit future uses.

data.name: S4023_Description
data.value: Empty interfaces are usually used as a marker or a way to identify groups of types. The preferred way to achieve this is to use custom attributes.

data.name: S4025_Description
data.value: Having a field in a child class with a name that differs from a parent class' field only by capitalization is sure to cause confusion. Such child class fields should be renamed.

data.name: S4025_Title
data.value: Child class fields should not differ from parent class fields only by capitalization

data.name: S4026_Description
data.value: It is important to inform the ResourceManager of the language used to display the resources of the neutral culture for an assembly. This improves lookup performance for the first resource loaded.

data.name: S4027_Description
data.value: Exceptions types should provide the following constructors:

data.name: S4035_Description
data.value: When a class implements the IEquatable<T> interface, it enters a contract that, in effect, states "I know how to compare two instances of type T or any type derived from T for equality.". However if that class is derived, it is very unlikely that the base class will know how to make a meaningful comparison. Therefore that implicit contract is now broken.

data.name: S4039_Description
data.value: When a base type explicitly implements a public interface method, that method is only accessible in derived types through a reference to the current instance (namely this). If the derived type explicitly overrides that interface method, the base implementation becomes inaccessible.

data.name: S4039_Title
data.value: Interface methods should be callable by derived types

data.name: S4040_Description
data.value: Certain characters, once normalized to lowercase, cannot make a round trip. That is, they can not be converted from one locale to another and then accurately restored to their original characters.

data.name: S4040_Title
data.value: Strings should be normalized to uppercase

data.name: S4041_Description
data.value: When a type name matches the name of a publicly defined namespace, for instance one in the .NET framework class library, it leads to confusion and makes the library that much harder to use.

data.name: S4041_Title
data.value: Type names should not match namespaces

data.name: S4047_Description
data.value: When a reference parameter (keyword ref) is used, the passed argument type must exactly match the reference parameter type. This means that to be able to pass a derived type, it must be cast and assigned to a variable of the proper type. Use of generic methods eliminates that cumbersome down casting and should therefore be preferred.

data.name: S4047_Title
data.value: Generics should be used when appropriate

data.name: S4049_Description
data.value: Properties are accessed like fields which makes them easier to use.

data.name: S4050_Description
data.value: When implementing operator overloads, it is very important to make sure that all related operators and methods are consistent in their implementation.

data.name: S4052_Description
data.value: With the advent of .NET framework version 2, certain practices have become obsolete.

data.name: S4052_Title
data.value: Types should not extend outdated base types

data.name: S4055_Description
data.value: String literals embedded in the source code will not be localized properly.

data.name: S4055_Title
data.value: Literals should not be passed as localized parameters

data.name: S4056_Description
data.value: When a System.Globalization.CultureInfo or IFormatProvider object is not supplied, the default value that is supplied by the overloaded member might not have the effect that you want in all locales.

data.name: S4056_Title
data.value: Overloads with a "CultureInfo" or an "IFormatProvider" parameter should be used

data.name: S4057_Description
data.value: When you create a DataTable or DataSet, you should set the locale explicitly. By default, the locale for these types is the current culture. For data that is stored in a database or file and is shared globally, the locale should ordinarily be set to the invariant culture (CultureInfo.InvariantCulture).

data.name: S4057_Title
data.value: Locales should be set for data types

data.name: S4058_Description
data.value: Many string operations, the Compare and Equals methods in particular, provide an overload that accepts a StringComparison enumeration value as a parameter. Calling these overloads and explicitly providing this parameter makes your code clearer and easier to maintain.

data.name: S4058_Title
data.value: Overloads with a "StringComparison" parameter should be used

data.name: S4059_Description
data.value: Properties and Get method should have names that makes them clearly distinguishable.

data.name: S4059_Title
data.value: Property names should not match get methods

data.name: S4060_Description
data.value: The .NET framework class library provides methods for retrieving custom attributes. Sealing the attribute eliminates the search through the inheritance hierarchy, and can improve performance.

data.name: S4061_Description
data.value: A method using the VarArgs calling convention is not Common Language Specification (CLS) compliant and might not be accessible across programming languages, while the params keyword works the same way and is CLS compliant.

data.name: S4069_Description
data.value: Operator overloading is convenient but unfortunately not portable across languages. To be able to access the same functionality from another language you need to provide an alternate named method following the convention:

data.name: S4069_Title
data.value: Operator overloads should have named alternatives

data.name: S4070_Description
data.value: This rule raises an issue when an externally visible enumeration is marked with FlagsAttribute and one, or more, of its values is not a power of 2 or a combination of the other defined values.

data.name: S4070_Title
data.value: Non-flags enums should not be marked with "FlagsAttribute"

data.name: S4142_Description
data.value: There are valid cases for passing a variable multiple times into the same method call, but usually doing so is a mistake, and something else was intended for one of the arguments.

data.name: S4142_Title
data.value: Duplicate values should not be passed as arguments

data.name: S4144_Description
data.value: When two methods have the same implementation, either it was a mistake - something else was intended - or the duplication was intentional, but may be confusing to maintainers. In the latter case, one implementation should invoke the other.

data.name: S4144_Title
data.value: Methods should not have identical implementations

data.name: S4158_Description
data.value: When a collection is empty it makes no sense to access or iterate it. Doing so anyway is surely an error; either population was accidentally omitted or the developer doesn't understand the situation.

data.name: S4158_Title
data.value: Empty collections should not be accessed or iterated

data.name: S4159_Description
data.value: In the Attributed Programming Model, the ExportAttribute declares that a part "exports", or provides to the composition container, an object that fulfills a particular contract. During composition, parts with imports that have matching contracts will have those dependencies filled by the exported object.

data.name: S4200_Description
data.value: Native methods are functions that reside in libraries outside the virtual machine. Being able to call them is useful for interoperability with applications and libraries written in other programming languages, in particular when performing platform-specific operations. However doing so comes with extra risks since it means stepping out of the security model of the virtual machine. It is therefore highly recommended to take extra steps, like input validation, when invoking native methods. This is best done by making the native method private and by providing a wrapper that performs these extra steps and verifications.

data.name: S4210_Description
data.value: When an assembly uses Windows Forms (classes and interfaces from the System.Windows.Forms namespace) its entry point should be marked with the STAThreadAttribute to indicate that the threading model should be "Single-Threaded Apartment" (STA) which is the only one supported by Windows Forms.

data.name: S4210_Title
data.value: Windows Forms entry points should be marked with STAThread

data.name: S4212_Description
data.value: Because serialization constructors allocate and initialize objects, security checks that are present on regular constructors must also be present on a serialization constructor. Failure to do so would allow callers that could not otherwise create an instance to use the serialization constructor to do this.

data.name: S4214_Description
data.value: Methods marked with the System.Runtime.InteropServices.DllImportAttribute attribute use Platform Invocation Services to access unmanaged code and should not be exposed. Keeping them private or internal makes sure that their access is controlled and properly managed.

data.name: S4220_Description
data.value: When raising an event, two arguments are expected by the EventHandler delegate: Sender and event-data. There are three guidelines regarding these parameters:

data.name: S4225_Description
data.value: Creating an extension method that extends object is not recommended because it makes the method available on every type. Extensions should be applied at the most specialized level possible, and that is very unlikely to be object.

data.name: S4226_Description
data.value: It makes little sense to create an extension method when it is possible to just add that method to the type itself.

data.name: S4226_Title
data.value: Extensions should be in separate namespaces

data.name: S4260_Description
data.value: When creating a custom Markup Extension that accepts parameters in WPF, the ConstructorArgument markup must be used to identify the discrete properties that match these parameters. However since this is done via a string, the compiler will not notice if there are typos.

data.name: S4261_Description
data.value: According to the Task-based Asynchronous Pattern (TAP), methods returning either a System.Threading.Tasks.Task or a System.Threading.Tasks.Task<TResult> are considered "asynchronous". Such methods should use the "Async" suffix. Conversely methods which do not return such Tasks should not have an "Async" suffix in their names.

data.name: S4261_Title
data.value: Methods should be named according to their synchronicities

data.name: S4277_Description
data.value: Marking a class with PartCreationPolicy(CreationPolicy.Shared), which is part of Managed Extensibility Framework (MEF), means that a single, shared instance of the exported object will be created. Therefore it doesn't make sense to create new instances using the constructor and it will most likely result in unexpected behaviours.

data.name: S4277_Title
data.value: "Shared" parts should not be created with "new"

data.name: S4428_Description
data.value: The PartCreationPolicyAttribute attribute, which is part of the Managed Extensibility Framework (MEF), is used to specify how the exported object will be created. Therefore it doesn't make sense not to export this a class with this attribute using the ExportAttribute attribute.

data.name: S4456_Description
data.value: Because of the way yield methods are rewritten by the compiler (they become lazily evaluated state machines) any exceptions thrown during the parameters check will happen only when the collection is iterated over. That could happen far away from the source of the buggy code.

data.name: S4456_Title
data.value: Parameter validation in yielding methods should be wrapped

data.name: S4457_Description
data.value: Because of the way async/await methods are rewritten by the compiler, any exceptions thrown during the parameters check will happen only when the task is observed. That could happen far away from the source of the buggy code or never happen for fire-and-forget tasks.

data.name: S4457_Title
data.value: Parameter validation in "async"/"await" methods should be wrapped

data.name: S818_Description
data.value: Using upper case literal suffixes removes the potential ambiguity between "1" (digit 1) and "l" (letter el) for declaring literals.

data.name: S818_Title
data.value: Literal suffixes should be upper case

data.name: S907_Description
data.value: goto is an unstructured control flow statement. It makes code less readable and maintainable. Structured control flow statements such as if, for, while, continue or break should be used instead.

data.name: S927_Description
data.value: The name of a parameter in an externally visible method override does not match the name of the parameter in the base declaration of the method, or the name of the parameter in the interface declaration of the method or the name of any other partial definition.

data.name: S927_Title
data.value: parameter names should match base declaration and other partial definitions
